ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Slow at times, but a good way to maintain your Japanese skills. Hiroe-sensei is funny and very knowledgeable about many things, especially things related to Japanese academic writings (articles written by political scientists, politicians, old Japanese, etc.).

Fifth-Year Japanese is a pretty good way to keep your skills up, although its easy to forget some basic vocab from earlier Japanese courses. Professor Hiroe is experienced and knows his stuff. Hes always available to meet, which is helpful. The class is not as lively/energetic as the earlier years, but on the whole I am glad I took the class to keep up my Japanese. Youll encounter a good number of heritage learners in this class, and it helps your accent to listen to all of them. Also, there is no final exam, which makes the experience a lot less stressful.
